marketNews.title: 2024 Recap: Year of Rate Cuts and Elections
marketNews.content:
During 2024, expectations of interest rate cuts and their developments became the main focus of market participants and caused significant market volatility. At the end of 2023, the Fed projected that it would cut US interest rates by 75 basis points during 2024. However, unexpectedly, the Fed in April 2024 signaled a higher-for-longer stance and postponed the planned rate cuts as disinflation progressed slowly and the US labor market remained solid.

The Fed’s move put pressure on the rupiah exchange rate and prompted Bank Indonesia, also unexpectedly, to raise the BI Rate by 25 basis points in April 2024. Added to concerns about Indonesia’s fiscal prudence, the rupiah weakened against the US dollar to near 16,500 per dollar in June 2024, marking the lowest level since April 2020.

The situation reversed in 3Q24, when the rate-cut narrative regained strength in July 2024 as US employment data weakened. In September 2024, Bank Indonesia unexpectedly cut the policy rate by 25 basis points to 6% as the rupiah recovered to around 15,000 per dollar. In the same month, the Fed cut rates by 50 basis points, followed by a 25-basis-point cut in November 2024. The Fed ended 2024 with a 25-basis-point cut in December 2024, but projected a smaller series of US rate cuts in 2025.

The year was also a political year, with presidential elections in Indonesia and the United States. In Indonesia, President-elect Prabowo Subianto’s administration continued a plan to raise VAT to 12% starting 2025 to finance fiscal needs, despite weakening consumer purchasing power. In the United States, Donald Trump’s election victory created risks of a weaker Chinese economy and could push US inflation higher in the future due to his proposed protectionist policies.

marketNews.title: 1Q24
marketNews.content:
1Q24

- The government continued a rice social assistance program of 10 kg per month for 22 million recipients until June 2024 to mitigate the impact of El Niño. The program was then extended until December 2024.
- The government issued a VAT exemption (VAT DTP) of 100% for house purchases from 1 January to 30 June 2024 and a 50% exemption from 1 July to 31 December 2024.
- Prabowo Subianto‑Gibran Rakabuming Raka won the Indonesian presidential election. Their administration targets 8% economic growth, food and energy self‑sufficiency, and promotes a free nutritious meal program for school children and pregnant women.
- Gold price reached USD 2,195 per troy ounce on 8 March 2024 – an all-time high at that time – as the market expected the Fed to start cutting rates in the second half of 2024. Gold continued to rise, reaching another all-time high of USD 2,790 per troy ounce on 30 October 2024.

marketNews.title: 2Q24
marketNews.content:
2Q24

- Indonesia’s inflation in March 2024 reached 3.05% year-on-year, the highest in seven months. The increase was driven by food, beverage and tobacco inflation of 7.43% year-on-year, the highest since September 2022, due to El Niño effects.
- Brent crude oil price reached USD 92.14 per barrel on 12 April 2024, the highest level of 2024, amid the escalation of the Israel-Iran conflict.
- The Chinese government plans to issue bonds worth 1 trillion yuan to stimulate its slowing economy.

marketNews.title: 3Q24
marketNews.content:
3Q24

- Indonesia recorded monthly deflation for five consecutive months from May to September 2024.
- The Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources issued new regulations on gross-split contracts for the upstream oil and gas industry, allowing Contractual Work Cooperation (KKKS) entities to potentially receive a larger share of production revenue.
- The IDX (IHSG) reached an all-time high of 7,905 on 19 September 2024 as the Fed began cutting rates and projected a dovish rate-cut path for 2025.
- The government extended the 100% VAT exemption for house purchases until 31 December 2024.
- The government decided not to change the tobacco excise duty (CHT) rate for 2025 due to down-trading, but will increase the retail selling price.
- The People’s Bank of China (PBoC) cut the medium-term lending facility (MLF) rate by 30 basis points to 2% and announced several stimulus packages to support economic growth, aiming for a 5% year-on-year increase in 2024 as targeted by the Chinese government.

marketNews.title: 4Q24
marketNews.content:
4Q24

- Donald Trump won the US presidential election, driving the S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow Jones indices to all-time highs. Trump proposed import duties of 10-20% on all imported goods and 60% on products from China.
- Indonesia recorded inflation of 1.71% year-on-year in October 2024, the lowest since 2021.
- Finance Minister Sri Mulyani issued anti-dumping duties on imports of ceramic tiles from China. The measure applies for five years and imposes duties ranging from 13,446 to 94,544 rupiah per square meter.
- The US dollar index (DXY) strengthened to 106.9 on 14 November 2024, the highest level in one year, after Fed Chair Jerome Powell said the Fed would not rush to cut rates as the US economy remains solid.
- OPEC+ again postponed the oil production recovery for three months until April 2025 and extended the recovery period from 12 months to 18 months. This decision marks the third postponement of production recovery by OPEC+ due to weak demand and a surge in non-OPEC production.
- The government announced that the average minimum wage increase for 2025 will be 6.5%.
- The government confirmed the VAT increase from 11% to 12% effective 1 January 2025.
- The government announced several incentives for 2025, including a 3% VAT exemption on hybrid cars, extension of the house-purchase VAT exemption, food and electricity assistance, and support for labor-intensive sectors.

marketNews.title: IHSG Performance 2024
marketNews.content:
IHSG Performance 2024

During 2024, the IDX fell 3.2% year-to-date to a level of 7,037 as of 27 December 2024, performing worse than 2023 when it rose 6.2%. As in the previous year, the IDX performance was driven by conglomerate stocks that posted strong gains, such as DSSA (+361% YTD), TPIA (+39% YTD), AMMN (+26%), PANI (+227%) and BREN (+23% YTD). Meanwhile, blue-chip stocks including several big banks – BBRI (‑22% YTD) and BBNI (‑15% YTD) – ASII (‑3% YTD) and TLKM (‑26% YTD) tended to weaken during the year. Overall, the IDX still recorded foreign inflows of 17.4 trillion rupiah YTD, smaller than the 60.5 trillion rupiah in 2023.

Sectorally, the energy sector delivered the best performance with a 27% YTD gain, driven by DSSA (+361% YTD) and ADRO (+83% YTD). The transportation sector posted the worst performance with a 19% YTD decline, driven by TAXI (‑86% YTD) and BLTA (‑58% YTD).

As of 23 December 2024, 41 issuers conducted IPOs, lower than the 78 issuers the previous year. Of those, 22 issuers saw their share prices rise, with an average increase of 80% as of 23 December 2024. The remaining 19 issuers experienced price declines, with an average drop of 46% as of the same date. DAAZ was the IPO stock with the highest price increase of 377%, while MPIX recorded the deepest price decline of 79%.
